Zero-Shot 32-shot ICL TV FV PCA-ICV LoRA L-ICV (Ours)
VQAv2 29.25 56.18 43.68 30.21 34.75 49.02 58.54

references:
We present performance comparisons with various methods in TableÂ 1.
Certain existing methods show only marginal improvements over Zero-Shot baselines, e.g., FV improves by 0.96/0.48 on VQAv2/OKVQA and PCA-ICV improves by 0.04 on OKVQA. Besides, we observe that all the previous non-learnable ICV methods do not reach the performance of the standard 32-shot ICL, e.g., the best non-learnable method, TV, is still 12.5/15.8 lower than 32-shot ICL on VQAv2/OKVQA. In contrast, our L-ICV achieves an accuracy improvement of 2.36 on VQAv2 and 1.6 on OKVQA over 32-shot ICL.
These results highlight the inefficacy of non-learnable methods in capturing essential task-specific information for VQA, whereas L-ICV, by leveraging diverse 32-shot ICL demonstrations for each query during training, manages to abstract useful task information effectively. We further show that our L-ICV outperforms LoRA with less trainable parameters, suggesting L-ICV can abstract task information more efficiently.

From FigureÂ 5, we can find that 32-shot ICL exhibits a significant shift compared to Zero-Shot, visualizing the shift effects given in Eq.Â 4. Considering both TableÂ 4 andÂ 1, we find that the shift direction similarity has positive correlation to the accuracy: if a method has large direction similarity, it also has better performance. For example, among non-learnable methods, TV has higher shift direction similarity than other ones, then it has better accuracy in TableÂ 1. Furthermore, for L-ICV which has the best accuracy in TableÂ 1, its shift direction similarity is also the highest, which is 0.742/0.829 on VQAv2/OKVQA, validating that L-ICV can produce shifts in query samples similar to 32-shot ICL, as visualized in FigureÂ 5. Such positive correlation validates the effectiveness of our motivation that a single L-ICV can indeed simulate the ICL capability of LMMs by shifting the direction of the query representation.

references: We calculate the ğ’‘ğ’‘\bm{p} of the vectors got from different methods in VQAv2 and select the top-101010 tokens with the highest probabilities in ğ’‘ğ’‘\bm{p} shown in TableÂ 5. We can see that the tokens got from FV are not highly relevant to the VQA task, which proves that FV does not capture the task information of VQAv2. On the other hand, the frequency of "yes" and "no" tokens is relatively high in the decoding results of PCA-ICV and TV, suggesting that they prefer to capture the simple patterns from demonstrations, e.g.yes/no, but struggle to grasp the overall task information of complex VQA. In contrast, the tokens of L-ICV decoding are not biased to specific answers like yes/no, suggesting it abstracts more summary task knowledge of VQA.

VQA contains various answer types and for convenience, VQAv2 divides them into three categories: â€œyes/noâ€, â€œnumberâ€, and â€œotherâ€. After delving deeper into the answer details, interestingly, we find that TV frequently answers â€œyes or noâ€ to number/other questions as shown in FigureÂ 6 (1)(2)(3). We term this phenomenon the yes/no hallucination and count the frequency of the yes/no hallucination over all test data samples for different methods in TableÂ 6. We can find that TV appears 111111111 times of yes/no hallucination, being consistent with the observations in TableÂ 5, suggesting TV is biased to yes/no type question. We also observe that non-learnable methods tend to respond meaningless text (e.g.â€œ\n\absentn\backslash\text{n}â€) when responding to â€œnumber/otherâ€ questions as shown in FigureÂ 6 (1)(2)(4). TableÂ 6 shows the number of meaningless answers. We find that PCA-ICV and TV have more chance to return meaningless answers for â€œotherâ€ questions, suggesting these methods do not capture the overall task information of VQA and are not able to answer some less frequently appeared questions. However, for L-ICV, it has less yes/no hallucination and meaningless responses, validating that L-ICV captures more robust task information of VQA.

The average token length during the forward inference is 38 tokens for Zero-Shot and L-ICV, 107 tokens for 4-shot ICL, 187 tokens for 8-shot ICL, 330 tokens for 16-shot ICL, and 633 tokens for 32-shot ICL.

PCA-ICV: PCA-ICV employs a weighting factor Î±ğ›¼\alpha to regulate the degree of interference ICV has on the model. We test various values of Î±ğ›¼\alpha to assess performance. Table Â 15 shows the results of PCA-ICV on VQAv2 and OKVQA datasets with different Î±ğ›¼\alpha value and extract samples. It is evident that the optimal alpha for the VQAv2 dataset significantly differs from that for OKVQA.
The optimal result of PCA-ICV on VQAv2 is 34.75 when alpha is set to 1e-2, while the best result for PCA-ICV is 30.59 when alpha is set to 1e-5.

A3.T16.caption: Table 16: Accuracy (%) for 32-shot ICL, task-specific L-ICV, General L-ICV.
A3.T16.table:
Methods 32-shot ICL L-ICV General L-ICV
VQAv2 56.18 58.54 56.17
OKVQA 48.48 50.08 49.52
references:
L-ICV is essentially a shift vector, allowing us to control the shift directions of query representations, which means we can control the shift direction of LMMs by adding or subtracting different shift vectors. Therefore, we can use several L-ICV trained on different VQA dataset to get the General L-ICV.
Specifically, given the diverse VQA task set ğ‘»={ğ’•1,â€¦,ğ’•n}ğ‘»subscriptğ’•1â€¦subscriptğ’•ğ‘›\bm{T}=\{\bm{t}_{1},\dots,\bm{t}_{n}\}, where ğ’•isubscriptğ’•ğ‘–\bm{t}_{i} is a VQA task and nğ‘›n is the number of tasks, we train the task-specific L-ICV ğ‘½i={ğ’—1i,â€¦,ğ’—Li}superscriptğ‘½ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ’—1ğ‘–â€¦superscriptsubscriptğ’—ğ¿ğ‘–\bm{V}^{i}=\{\bm{v}_{1}^{i},\dots,\bm{v}_{L}^{i}\} and the weight factor ğœ¶i={Î±1i,â€¦,Î±Li}superscriptğœ¶ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ›¼1ğ‘–â€¦superscriptsubscriptğ›¼ğ¿ğ‘–\bm{\alpha}^{i}=\{\alpha_{1}^{i},\dots,\alpha_{L}^{i}\} on each VQA dataset. Then, we have the L-ICV set ğ’±sâ€‹eâ€‹t={ğ‘½1,â€¦,ğ‘½n}subscriptğ’±ğ‘ ğ‘’ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘½1â€¦superscriptğ‘½ğ‘›\mathcal{V}_{set}=\{\bm{V}^{1},\dots,\bm{V}^{n}\} and its weight factors set ğœ¶sâ€‹eâ€‹t={ğœ¶1,â€¦,ğœ¶n}subscriptğœ¶ğ‘ ğ‘’ğ‘¡superscriptğœ¶1â€¦superscriptğœ¶ğ‘›\bm{\alpha}_{set}=\{\bm{\alpha}^{1},\dots,\bm{\alpha}^{n}\}. The General L-ICV has the same shape of task-specific L-ICV. For the lğ‘™l-th layer, it is defined as ğ’—l=âˆ‘iğœ¶liâ€‹ğ’—lisubscriptğ’—ğ‘™subscriptğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğœ¶ğ‘™ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ’—ğ‘™ğ‘–\bm{v}_{l}=\sum_{i}\bm{\alpha}_{l}^{i}\bm{v}_{l}^{i}. During inference, we use the vector ğ’—lsubscriptğ’—ğ‘™\bm{v}_{l} to shift the original representation, resulting in hâ€‹(x^i)â€²=hâ€‹(x^i)+ğ’—lâ„superscriptsubscript^ğ‘¥ğ‘–â€²â„subscript^ğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ’—ğ‘™h(\hat{x}_{i})^{\prime}=h(\hat{x}_{i})+\bm{v}_{l}. We average the L-ICV trained in OKVQA and VQAv2 to get the general ICV and evaluate the performance of the general ICV ğ‘½g={ğ’—1,â€¦,ğ’—L}subscriptğ‘½ğ‘”subscriptğ’—1â€¦subscriptğ’—ğ¿\bm{V}_{g}=\{\bm{v}_{1},\dots,\bm{v}_{L}\} on OKVQA and VQAv2, with the results presented on TableÂ 16.
